Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Expectation2: Perform assigned physical tasks and material handling efficiently.
Situation2: A carpenter is waiting for you to bring them the next load of lumber so they can continue their work without interruption.
Story: I wipe the sweat from my brow, the sun beating down on the construction site as I hurry to grab another load of lumber for the carpenter. He’s waiting, tapping his foot, and I know if I’m slow, the whole crew will be held up. My arms ache, but I push through, trying to keep up with the pace everyone expects. Just as I hoist the next board, my phone buzzes in my pocket. It’s a message from Mom: “Can you call when you get a break? Dad seems quiet today.” My chest tightens. I know they count on me to check in, to ask if everything’s okay, to be the one who holds us together at home. But here, I’m just another pair of hands, and if I stop now, I’ll let the team down. I stand there, torn, the weight of the lumber in my arms and the weight of my family’s needs pressing on my heart, unsure which burden to set down first.
